{{short description|American novelist and short story writer}} {{Infobox writer | name = John Cheever | image = Johncheever.jpg | birth_name = John William Cheever | birth_date = {{Birth date|1912|5|27}} | birth_place = [[Quincy, Massachusetts]], U.S. | death_date = {{Death date and age|1982|6|18|1912|5|27}} | death_place = [[Ossining (village), New York|Ossining]], New York, U.S. | occupation = Writer, novelist | nationality = American | period = [[20th century in literature|20th century]] | genre = [[Short story]], fiction | movement = [[Symbolism (arts)|Symbolism]] | notableworks = {{hlist|''[[The Enormous Radio]]''|''[[The Five-Forty-Eight]]''|''[[The Wapshot Chronicle]]''|''[[The Swimmer (short story)|The Swimmer]]''|''[[The Wapshot Scandal]]''|''[[Bullet Park]]''|''[[Falconer (novel)|Falconer]]''|''[[Oh What a Paradise It Seems]]''}} | spouse = {{marriage|Mary Winternitz|1941|2014|end=d.}} | children = [[Susan Cheever|Susan]]
[[Benjamin Cheever|Benjamin]]
Federico | awards = [[Pulitzer Prize for Fiction|Pulitzer Prize]] (1979)
[[National Book Critics Circle Award]] (1981) | years_active = 1935–1982 }} '''John William Cheever''' (May 27, 1912 – June 18, 1982) was an American novelist and short story writer. He is sometimes called "the [[Anton Chekhov|Chekhov]] of the suburbs".{{cite news| url = https://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/22/nyregion/home-of-cheever-chekhov-of-the-suburbs-is-for-sale.html | work=[[The New York Times]] | title= Home of Cheever, Chekhov of the Suburbs, Is for Sale| first= Lisa W. |last=Foderaro | date= July 21, 2014 |accessdate= November 11, 2015}}{{cite news | url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/books/authors/john-cheever-master-of-the-short-story/ | work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] | location= UK| title=John Cheever: 'the Chekhov of the suburbs' | first= Martin |last=Chilton|date= October 15, 2015|accessdate= November 11, 2015}} His fiction is mostly set in the [[Upper East Side]] of [[Manhattan]], the [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester]] suburbs, old [[New England]] villages based on various [[South Shore (Massachusetts)|South Shore]] towns around [[Quincy, Massachusetts]], where he was born, and Italy, especially [[Rome]]. He is "now recognized as one of the most important short fiction writers of the 20th century."''Contemporary Literary Criticism'', [http://www.enotes.com/short-story-criticism/cheever-john "John Cheever Criticism"]. Enotes.com. Accessed 20 February 2010. While Cheever is perhaps best remembered for his short stories (including "[[The Enormous Radio]]", "Goodbye, My Brother", "[[The Five-Forty-Eight]]", "The Country Husband", and "[[The Swimmer (short story)|The Swimmer]]"), he also wrote four novels, comprising ''[[The Wapshot Chronicle]]'' ([[National Book Award]], 1958), [http://www.nationalbook.org/nba1958.html "National Book Awards – 1958"]. [[National Book Foundation]]. Retrieved 2012-03-14.
(With essay by [[Neil Baldwin (writer)|Neil Baldwin]] [http://www.nationalbook.org/nbaclassics_jcheever.html] from the Awards 50-year anniversary publications and from the Awards 60-year anniversary blog.) {{cite web|url=http://www.nationalbook.org/nba1958.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-02-09 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151019034308/http://www.nationalbook.org/nba1958.html |archivedate=October 19, 2015 |df= }} ''[[The Wapshot Scandal]]'' ([[William Dean Howells Medal]], 1965), ''[[Bullet Park]]'' (1969), ''[[Falconer (novel)|Falconer]]'' (1977) and a novella ''[[Oh What a Paradise It Seems]]'' (1982). His main themes include the duality of human nature: sometimes dramatized as the disparity between a character's decorous social persona and inner corruption, and sometimes as a conflict between two characters (often brothers) who embody the salient aspects of both – light and dark, flesh and spirit. Many of his works also express a nostalgia for a vanishing way of life (as evoked by the mythical St. Botolphs in the ''Wapshot'' novels), characterized by abiding cultural traditions and a profound sense of community, as opposed to the alienating nomadism of modern [[suburbia]]. A compilation of his short stories, ''[[The Stories of John Cheever]]'', won the 1979 [[Pulitzer Prize for Fiction]] and a [[National Book Critics Circle Award]], and its first paperback edition won a 1981 National Book Award. [https://www.nationalbook.org/awards-prizes/national-book-awards-1981 "National Book Awards – 1981"]. National Book Foundation. Retrieved 2012-03-14.
With essays by Willie Perdomo, Matthew Pitt, and Robert Wilder from the Awards 60-year anniversary blog. Cheever's ''Stories'' won the 1981 [[National Book Award for Fiction#1980 to 1989|award for paperback Fiction]].
From 1980 to 1983 in [[National Book Awards#History|National Book Awards history]] there were dual hardcover and paperback awards in most categories. Most of the paperback award-winners were reprints, including this one. On April 27, 1982, six weeks before his death, Cheever was awarded the National Medal for Literature by the [[American Academy of Arts and Letters]]. His work has been included in the [[Library of America]]. ==Early life and education== John William Cheever was born in [[Quincy, Massachusetts]], the second child of Frederick Lincoln Cheever and Mary Liley Cheever. His father was a prosperous shoe salesman, and Cheever spent much of his childhood in a large [[Victorian house]], at 123 Winthrop Avenue,Susan Cheever, ''Home Before Dark: A Personal Memoir of John Cheever by His Daughter'' (New York: Houghton Mifflin, 1984), 84. in the then-genteel suburb of [[Wollaston (Quincy, Massachusetts)|Wollaston, Massachusetts]]. In the mid-1920s, however, as the New England shoe and textile industries began their long decline, Frederick Cheever lost most of his money and began to drink heavily. To pay the bills, Mary Cheever opened a gift shop in downtown Quincy—an "abysmal humiliation" for the family, as John saw it.From Cheever's unpublished journal, on deposit at Houghton Library, Harvard University. In 1926, Cheever began attending [[Thayer Academy]], a private day school, but he found the atmosphere stifling and performed poorly, and finally transferred to [[Quincy High School (Massachusetts)|Quincy High]] in 1928. A year later he won a short story contest sponsored by the ''[[Boston Herald]]'' and was invited back to Thayer as a "special student" on academic probation. His grades continued to be poor, however, and, in March 1930, he was either expelled for smoking or (more likely) departed of his own accord when the headmaster delivered an ultimatum to the effect that he must either apply himself or leave. The 18-year-old Cheever wrote a sardonic account of this experience, titled "Expelled", which was subsequently published in ''[[The New Republic]]''. (1930).Jon [''sic''] Cheever, "Expelled", ''[[The New Republic]]'', October 1, 1930, 171–4. Around this time, Cheever's older brother Fred, forced to withdraw from [[Dartmouth College|Dartmouth]] in 1926 because of the family's financial crisis, re-entered Cheever's life "when the situation was most painful and critical," as Cheever later wrote. After the 1932 [[Kreuger crash|crash]] of [[Kreuger & Toll]], in which Frederick Cheever had invested what was left of his money, the Cheever house on Winthrop Avenue was lost to foreclosure. The parents separated, while John and Fred took an apartment together on [[Beacon Hill, Boston, Massachusetts|Beacon Hill]], in [[Boston, Massachusetts|Boston]]. In 1933, John wrote to Elizabeth Ames, the director of the [[Yaddo| Yaddo artist's colony]] in [[Saratoga Springs, New York]]: "The idea of leaving the city," he said, "has never been so distant or desirable."''The Letters of John Cheever'', ed. Benjamin Cheever (New York: Simon and Schuster, 1988), p. 33. Ames denied his first application but offered him a place the following year, whereupon Cheever decided to sever his "ungainly attachment" to his brother. Cheever spent the summer of 1934 at Yaddo, which would serve as a second home for much of his life.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} ==Career== ===Early writings=== For the next few years, Cheever divided his time between Manhattan, Saratoga, [[Lake George (New York)|Lake George]] (where he was caretaker of the Yaddo-owned Triuna Island), and Quincy, where he continued to visit his parents, who had reconciled and moved to an apartment at 60 Spear Street. Cheever drove from one place to another in a dilapidated [[Ford Model A (1927)|Model A]] roadster, but had no permanent address. In 1935, [[Katharine Sergeant Angell White|Katharine White]] of ''[[The New Yorker]]'' bought Cheever's story "Buffalo", for $45—the first of many that Cheever would publish in the magazine. [[Maxim Lieber]] became his literary agent, 1935–1941. In 1938, he began work for the [[Federal Writers' Project]] in [[Washington, D. C.]], which he considered an embarrassing boondoggle. As an editor for the ''WPA Guide to New York City'', Cheever was charged with (as he put it) "twisting into order the sentences written by some incredibly lazy bastards."''The Letters of John Cheever'', ed. Benjamin Cheever (New York: Simon and Schuster, 1988), 47. He quit after less than a year and a few months later he met his future wife, Mary Winternitz, seven years his junior. She was a daughter of Milton Winternitz, dean of [[Yale Medical School]], and granddaughter of [[Thomas A. Watson]], an assistant to Alexander Graham Bell during the invention of the telephone. They married in 1941. Cheever enlisted in the Army on May 7, 1942. His first collection of short stories, ''The Way Some People Live'', was published in 1943 to mixed reviews. Cheever himself came to despise the book as "embarrassingly immature", and for the rest of his life to destroyed every copy he could lay his hands on. However, the book may have saved his life after falling into the hands of Major [[Leonard Spigelgass]], an [[MGM]] executive and officer in the [[United States Army Signal Corps|Army Signal Corps]], who was struck by Cheever's "childlike sense of wonder".''Glad Tidings: A Friendship in Letters'', ed. John D. Weaver (New York: Harper Collins, 1993), 58. Early that summer, Cheever was transferred to the former [[Paramount Pictures|Paramount]] studio in [[Astoria, Queens]], New York City, where he commuted via subway from his apartment in [[Chelsea, Manhattan|Chelsea]], Manhattan, New York City. Meanwhile, most of his old infantry company was killed on a Normandy beach during the [[D-Day|D-Day invasion]]. Cheever's daughter Susan was born on July 31, 1943. After the war, Cheever moved his family to an apartment building at 400 East 59th Street, near [[York Avenue / Sutton Place|Sutton Place]], Manhattan; almost every morning for the next five years, he would dress in his only suit and take the elevator to a maid's room in the basement, where he stripped to his boxer shorts and wrote until lunchtime. In 1946, he accepted a $4,800 advance from [[Random House]] to resume work on his novel, ''The Holly Tree'', which he had discontinued during the war. "The Enormous Radio" appeared in the May 17, 1947, issue of ''The New Yorker'' — a Kafkaesque tale about a sinister radio that broadcasts the private conversations of tenants in a New York apartment building. A startling advance on Cheever's early, more naturalistic work, the story elicited a fan letter from the magazine's irascible editor, [[Harold Ross]]: "It will turn out to be a memorable one, or I am a fish."''Letters from the Editor: The New Yorker's Harold Ross'', ed. Thomas Kunkel (New York: Modern Library, 2000), 308. Cheever's son Benjamin was born on May 4, 1948. ===Mid-career=== Cheever's work became longer and more complex, apparently a protest against the "[[slice of life]]" fiction typical of ''The New Yorker'' in those years. An early draft of "The Day the Pig Fell into the Well"—a long story with elaborate Chekhovian nuances, meant to "operate something like a [[rondo]]", as Cheever wrote to his friend and ''New Yorker'' editor [[William Keepers Maxwell, Jr.|William Maxwell]]—was completed in 1949, though the magazine did not make space for it until five years later. In 1951, Cheever wrote "Goodbye, My Brother", after a gloomy summer in [[Martha's Vineyard]]. Largely on the strength of these two stories (still in manuscript at the time), Cheever was awarded a [[Guggenheim Fellowship]]. On May 28, 1951, Cheever moved to [[Beechwood (Vanderlip mansion)|Beechwood]], the suburban estate of Frank A. Vanderlip, a banker,[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/03/nyregion/connecticut/03cheeverCT.html?pagewanted=1&_r=1 "How Cheever Really Felt About Living in Suburbia"] by [[Joseph Berger (author)|Joseph Berger]], ''The New York Times'', April 30, 2009 (p. CT1, 5/3/09, CT ed.). Retrieved 5/2/09. in the Westchester hamlet of [[Scarborough-on-Hudson]], where he rented a small cottage on the edge of the estate. The house, coincidentally, had been occupied before the Cheevers by another suburban chronicler, [[Richard Yates (novelist)|Richard Yates]]. In Scarborough, he was a casual volunteer for the [[Briarcliff Manor Fire Department]]. Cheever's second collection, ''The Enormous Radio'', was published in 1953. Reviews were mostly positive, though Cheever's reputation continued to suffer because of his close association with ''The New Yorker'' (considered middlebrow by such influential critics as [[Dwight Macdonald]]), and he was particularly pained by the general preference for [[J. D. Salinger]]'s ''[[Nine Stories (Salinger)|Nine Stories]]'', published around the same time. Meanwhile, Random House demanded that Cheever either produce a publishable novel or pay back his advance, whereupon Cheever wrote Mike Bessie at [[Harper & Brothers]] ("These old bones are up for sale"), who bought him out of his Random House contract. In the summer of 1956, Cheever finished ''The Wapshot Chronicle'' while vacationing in Friendship, [[Maine]], and received a congratulatory telegram from William Maxwell: "WELL ROARED LION."''The Letters of John Cheever'', 179. With the proceeds from the sale of film rights to "The Housebreaker of Shady Hill", Cheever and his family spent the following year in Italy, where his son Federico was born on March 9, 1957 ("We wanted to call him Frederick", Cheever wrote, "but there is of course no K in the alphabet here and I gave up after an hour or two").''The Letters of John Cheever'', 196. ''The Wapshot Scandal'' was published in 1964, and received perhaps the best reviews of Cheever's career up to that point (amid quibbles about the novel's episodic structure). Cheever appeared on the cover of ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine's March 27 issue, this for an appreciative profile, "Ovid in Ossining". (In 1961 Cheever had moved to a stately, stone-ended [[Dutch Colonial]] farmhouse in Ossining, on the east bank of the [[Hudson River|Hudson]].) "The Swimmer" appeared in the July 18, 1964 issue of ''The New Yorker''. Cheever noted with chagrin that the story (one of his best) appeared toward the back of the issue—behind a [[John Updike]] story—since, as it happened, Maxwell and other editors at the magazine were a little bewildered by its non-''New Yorker''ish surrealism. In the summer of 1966, a screen adaptation of "The Swimmer", starring [[Burt Lancaster]], was filmed in Westport, Connecticut. Cheever was a frequent visitor on the set, and made a cameo appearance in the movie. By then Cheever's alcoholism had become severe, exacerbated by torment concerning his bisexuality. Still, he blamed most of his marital woes on his wife, and in 1966 he consulted a psychiatrist, David C. Hays, about her hostility and "needless darkness". After a session with Mary Cheever, the psychiatrist asked to see the couple jointly; Cheever, heartened, believed his wife's difficult behavior would finally be addressed. At the joint session, however, Hays said (as Cheever noted in his journal) that Cheever himself was the problem: "a neurotic man, narcissistic, egocentric, friendless, and so deeply involved in [his] own defensive illusions that [he has] invented a manic-depressive wife."''The Journals of John Cheever'', ed. Robert Gottlieb (New York: Alfred A. Knopf, 1991), 214. Cheever soon terminated therapy. ===Later life and career=== ''Bullet Park'' was published in 1969, and received a devastating review from [[Benjamin DeMott]] on the front page of ''[[The New York Times Book Review]]'': "John Cheever's short stories are and will remain lovely birds... But in the gluey atmosphere of ''Bullet Park'' no birds sing."Benjamin DeMott, ''[[New York Times Book Review]]'', April 27, 1969, 1, 40–1. Cheever's alcoholic depression deepened, and in May he resumed psychiatric treatment (which again proved fruitless). He began an affair with actress [[Hope Lange]] in the late 1960s.{{cite book | title = John Cheever | publisher = ''iUniverse'' | year = 2001 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=1DecfKQ6vU0C&pg=PA237&lpg=PA237&dq=hope+lange+frank+sinatra | accessdate = 2008-10-31 | isbn = 978-0-595-21138-8 }} On May 12, 1973, Cheever awoke coughing uncontrollably, and learned at the hospital that he had almost died from [[pulmonary edema]] caused by alcoholism. After a month in the hospital, he returned home vowing never to drink again; however, he resumed drinking in August. Despite his precarious health, he spent the fall semester teaching (and drinking, both with fellow writer-teacher, [[Raymond Carver#Writing career|Raymond Carver]]{{cite news | last = Ebert | first = Roger | coauthors = | title = ''Short Cuts'' | work = | pages = | publisher = [[Chicago Sun-Times]] | date = October 22, 1993 | url = http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/classifieds?category=REVIEWS01&TITLESearch=Short%20Cuts&ToDate=20101231 | accessdate = 2010-01-05 }}) at the [[Iowa Writers' Workshop]], where his students included [[T. Coraghessan Boyle|T. C. Boyle]], [[Allan Gurganus]], and [[Ron Hansen (novelist)|Ron Hansen]]. As his marriage continued to deteriorate, Cheever accepted a professorship at [[Boston University]] the following year and moved into a fourth-floor walkup apartment at 71 Bay State Road. Cheever's drinking soon became suicidal and, in March 1975, his brother Fred, now virtually indigent, but sober after his own lifelong bout with alcoholism, drove John back to Ossining. On April 9, Cheever was admitted to the Smithers Alcoholic Rehabilitation Unit in New York, where he shared a bedroom and bath with four other men. Driven home by his wife on May 7, Cheever never drank alcohol again. In March 1977, Cheever appeared on the cover of ''[[Newsweek]]'' with the caption, "A Great American Novel: John Cheever's ''[[Falconer (novel)|Falconer]].''" The novel was No. 1 on the [[New York Times Best Seller list|''New York Times'' Best Seller list]] for three weeks. ''The Stories of John Cheever'' appeared in October 1978, and became one of the most successful collections ever, selling 125,000 copies in hardback and winning universal acclaim. Cheever was awarded the [[Edward MacDowell Medal]] for outstanding contribution to the arts by the [[MacDowell Colony]] in 1979. ==Illness and death== In the summer of 1981, a tumor was discovered in Cheever's right lung, and, in late November, he returned to the hospital and learned that the cancer had spread to his femur, pelvis, and bladder. Cheever's last novel, ''[[Oh What a Paradise It Seems]],'' was published in March 1982; only 100 pages long and relatively inferior (as Cheever himself suspected), the book received respectful reviews in part because it was widely known the author was dying of cancer. On April 27, he received the National Medal for Literature at [[Carnegie Hall]], where colleagues were shocked by Cheever's ravaged appearance after months of cancer therapy. "A page of good prose", he declared in his remarks, "remains invincible." As [[John Updike]] remembered, "All the literary acolytes assembled there fell quite silent, astonished by such faith." Cheever died on June 18, 1982.{{cite news |first= Michiko|last= Kakutani|authorlink= |coauthors= |title=John Cheever Is Dead At 70. Novelist Won Pulitzer Prize. |url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F00913FF3F5F0C7A8DDDAF0894DA484D81 |quote= |publisher=New York Times |date=June 19, 1982}} The flags in Ossining were lowered to half staff for 10 days after Cheever's death.{{Cite book | last = Minzesheimer | first = Bob | title = The John Cheever Reading Room | publisher = Ossining Public Library | date = | url =http://www.ossininglibrary.org/pages/aboutTheLibrary/cheever.html }} He is buried at First Parish Cemetery, [[Norwell, Massachusetts]].Wilson, Scott. ''Resting Places: The Burial Sites of More Than 14,000 Famous Persons'', 3d ed.: 2 (Kindle Location 8214). McFarland & Company, Inc., Publishers. Kindle Edition. ===Posthumous=== In 1987, Cheever's widow, Mary, signed a contract with a small publisher, Academy Chicago, for the right to publish Cheever's uncollected short stories. The contract led to a long legal battle and a book of 13 stories by the author entitled ''Fall River and Other Uncollected Stories'', published in 1994 by [[Academy Chicago Publishers]]. Two of Cheever's children, [[Susan Cheever|Susan]] and [[Benjamin Cheever|Benjamin]], became writers. Susan's memoir, ''Home Before Dark'' (1984), revealed Cheever's bisexuality, which was confirmed by his posthumously published letters and journals. This was parodied to comedic effect in [[The Cheever Letters|a 1992 episode of]] the TV sitcom ''[[Seinfeld]]'', when the character Susan discovers explicit love letters from Cheever to her father. After [[Blake Bailey]] published his biography of [[Richard Yates (novelist)|Richard Yates]], ''A Tragic Honesty'' (2003), Cheever's son Ben suggested Bailey write an authoritative biography of Cheever. The book was published by [[Alfred A. Knopf|Knopf]] on March 10, 2009 and won that year's [[National Book Critics Circle Award]] in Biography and the [[Francis Parkman Prize]], and was a finalist for the [[Pulitzer Prize|Pulitzer]] and [[James Tait Black Memorial Prize]].Wolff, Geoffrey. "[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/15/books/review/Wolff-t.html Suburban Suffering]," [[New York Times Book Review]]'', 15 March 2009, 1, 8-9. Also in 2009, Cheever was featured in ''Soul of a People: Writing America's Story'', a 90-minute documentary about the WPA Writers' Project.{{cite web|url=http://www.smithsonianchannel.com/site/smithsonian/show_soul_people_writers.do |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120912055114/http://www.smithsonianchannel.com/site/smithsonian/show_soul_people_writers.do |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-09-12 |title=''Soul of a People: Writing America's Story'' |publisher=Smithsonianchannel.com |date=2013-02-06 |accessdate=2013-12-05 }} His life during the 1930s is also highlighted in the companion book, ''Soul of a People: The WPA Writers' Project Uncovers Depression America''.[http://www.wiley.com/WileyCDA/WileyTitle/productCd-0470403802.html ''Soul of a People: The WPA Writers' Project Uncovers Depression America''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121007072915/http://www.wiley.com/WileyCDA/WileyTitle/productCd-0470403802.html |date=2012-10-07 }}. Cheever's name is mentioned in the lyrics of 2017 song "Carin at the Liquor Store"{{Citation|last=The National|title=The National – 'Carin at the Liquor Store'|date=2017-08-08|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eEe_yCVLQSc|accessdate=2017-08-09}} by the American band [[The National (band)|The National]]. ==Works== ===Novels=== * ''[[The Wapshot Chronicle]]'' (1957) * ''[[The Wapshot Scandal]]'' (1964) * ''[[Bullet Park]]'' (1969) * ''[[Falconer (novel)|Falconer]]'' (1977) * ''[[Oh What a Paradise It Seems]]'' (1982) ===Short story collections=== * ''The Enormous Radio and Other Stories'' (1953) * ''The Housebreaker of Shady Hill and Other Stories'' (1958){{cite newspaper|author=Yardley, Jonathan|authorlink=Jonathan Yardley|title=John Cheever's 'Housebreaker,' Welcome as Ever|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=20 July 2004|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2004/07/20/AR2005033101176.html}} * ''Some People, Places and Things That Will Not Appear In My Next Novel'' (1961) * ''The Brigadier and the Golf Widow'' (1964) * ''The World of Apples'' (1973) * ''[[The Stories of John Cheever]]'' (1978) * ''Fall River and Other Uncollected Stories'' (1994) ===Collections=== * ''The Letters of John Cheever'', edited by Benjamin Cheever (1988) * ''The Journals of John Cheever'' (1991) * ''Collected Stories & Other Writings'' ([[Library of America]]) (stories, 2009) * ''Complete Novels'' (Library of America) (novels, 2009) ===Juvenilia=== * ''The Way Some People Live'' (1943) Cheever}} * {{cite journal| url=http://www.theparisreview.org/interviews/3667/the-art-of-fiction-no-62-john-cheever| work=The Paris Review| title=John Cheever, The Art of Fiction No. 62 |author=Annette Grant| date=Fall 1976}} * [http://xroads.virginia.edu/~MA95/dyer/cheever4.html ''John Cheever: Parody and The Suburban Aesthetic'' by John Dyer] * Founded in 1947, the '''Johns Hopkins Writing Seminars''' is an academic program offering undergraduate and graduate degrees in writing in the [[Johns Hopkins University School of Arts and Sciences|Zanvyl Krieger School of Arts & Sciences]] at [[Johns Hopkins University]]. It is the second-oldest creative writing program in the United States.
Notable faculty of the program have included [[Edward Albee]], [[John Barth]], [[Madison Smartt Bell]], [[J. M. Coetzee]], [[Mary Jo Salter]], [[Stephen Dixon (author)|Stephen Dixon]], [[Mark Hertsgaard]], [[Brad Leithauser]], [[John Irwin (academic)|John Irwin]], [[J.D. McClatchy]], [[Alice McDermott]], [[Mark Crispin Miller]], [[Andrew Motion]], [[Wyatt Prunty]], [[David St. John]], [[Mark Strand]], [[Robert Stone (novelist)|Robert Stone]], and [[David Yezzi]].<ref name="JHU writing about"/>
Writer [[David Yezzi]] currently chairs the program, which has a strong reputation.<ref name="www2.citypaper.com">{{cite news|url=http://www2.citypaper.com/news/story.asp?id=3725|title=Writers' Cramp, Days of Whine and Proses at the JHU Writing Seminars|work=City Paper|author=Eileen Murphy|date=March 18, 1998|accessdate=June 27, 2014}}</ref><ref name="JHU writing"/> It has been ranked "One of the Top Ten Graduate Programs in Creative Writing" by [[The Atlantic]].<ref>https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2007/08/the-best-of-the-best/306049/</ref> In 1997, ''[[US News and World Report]]'' ranked the program second in the United States out of sixty-five eligible full-residency MFA programs.<ref name="www2.citypaper.com"/><ref name="knol mfa"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1998-02-10/features/1998041109_1_writing-seminars-mark-strand-hopkins|title=Strand writes off JHU Literature|work=The Baltimore Sun|author=Mike Bowler|date=February 10, 1998}}</ref> In 2011, [[Poets & Writers]] ranked Hopkins seventeenth nationally out of 157 eligible full-residency MFA programs.<ref name="PW 2011"/> The long respected Science Writing program<ref>{{cite web|last=Zivkovic |first=Bora |url=http://blogs.scientificamerican.com/incubator/2012/01/19/science-writing-at-johns-hopkins/ |title=Science Writing at Johns Hopkins | The SA Incubator, Scientific American Blog Network |publisher=Blogs.scientificamerican.com |date= |accessdate=2015-03-10}}</ref> was closed down in 2013 as an on-campus program, but was re-established as an online/low residency program shortly thereafter.<ref>{{cite web|last=Straumsheim |first=Carl |url=http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2013/05/03/johns-hopkins-cuts-science-writing-program-masters-degree-students |title=Johns Hopkins cuts science writing program for master's degree students @insidehighered |publisher=Insidehighered.com |date=2013-03-25 |accessdate=2015-03-10}}</ref>
==Degree programs== * Writing Seminars B.A. Degree * MFA in Fiction and Poetry
==Notable graduates== {{colbegin}} *[[Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie]] *[[John Astin]] *[[Beth Bachmann]] *[[Russell Baker]] *[[Frederick Barthelme]] *[[Jeffrey Blitz]] *[[Paul Harris Boardman]] *[[Jennifer Finney Boylan]] *[[Lucie Brock-Broido]] *[[John Gregory Brown]] *[[Vikram Chandra (novelist)]] *[[Iris Chang]] *Julie Checkoway <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newvideo.com/filmmakers/julie-checkoway-biography/ |title=Julie Checkoway Biography - - Cinedigm Entertainment |publisher=Newvideo.com |date=2011-04-11 |accessdate=2015-03-10}}</ref> *[[Wes Craven]] *[[Erica Dawson]] *[[Elizabeth DeVita-Raeburn]] *[[Louise Erdrich]] *Mark Friedman<ref>{{cite web|url=http://web.jhu.edu/announcements/students/targetpage.html?baid=37431 |title=Student Announcement |publisher=Web.jhu.edu |date=2012-03-01 |accessdate=2015-03-10}}</ref> *[[Nell Greenfieldboyce]] *[[Martha Grimes]] *[[Rachel Hadas]] *[[Gil Scott-Heron]] *[[Lawrence Hill]] *[[Jay Hopler]] *[[Kimberly Johnson]] *[[Pagan Kennedy]] *[[Porochista Khakpour]] *[[The Pain, When Will it End|Tim Kreider]] *[[Phillis Levin]] *[[David Lipsky]] *[[Rosemary Mahoney]] *[[Emma Marris]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thebreakthrough.org/people/profile/emma-marris |title=The Breakthrough Institute - Emma Marris |publisher=Thebreakthrough.org |date= |accessdate=2015-03-10}}</ref> *Gardner McFall,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timebeing.com/poets/26-gardner-mcfall |title=Time Being Books Gardner McFall |publisher=Timebeing.com |date= |accessdate=2015-03-10}}</ref> *Tomás Q. Morín,<ref>{{cite web |author= |url=http://wp.vcu.edu/vcucollege/mfa-program-reading/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140106032025/http://wp.vcu.edu/vcucollege/mfa-program-reading/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2014-01-06 |title=VCU MFA Program Hosts Reading by Poets Tomas Morin and James Arthur | VCU College of Humanities and Sciences |publisher=Wp.vcu.edu |date=2013-10-28 |accessdate=2015-03-10 }}</ref> *[[ZZ Packer]] *[[Molly Peacock]] *[[Hollis Robbins]] *[[Deborah Rudacille]] *[[Natalie Shapero]] *[[Tom Sleigh]] *[[Elizabeth Spires]] *[[Lorin Stein]] *[[Susan Stewart (poet)|Susan Stewart]] *[[Rosanna Warren]] *[[Rachel Wetzsteon]] *[[Greg Williamson]] {{colend}}
==Turnbull Lectures== The Writing Seminars hosts the Turnbull Lectures, a yearly lecture series on the topic of poetry.<ref name="JHU turnbull"/> The series was established in 1891 and has run almost continuously between the years 1891-1984 and 2000–present.<ref name="JHU turnbull past"/> Recent lecturers have included [[Tracy K. Smith]], [[Terrance Hayes]], [[Richard Wilbur]], [[Paul Muldoon]], [[Stanley Plumly]], [[Edward Mendelson]], and [[Edna Longley]].<ref name="JHU turnbull past"/><ref name="JHU turnbull2"/><ref name="JHU turnbull3"/>
==See also== * ''[[The Hopkins Review]]''
==External links== * [http://writingseminars.jhu.edu Writing Seminars homepage at the JHU website]

The History | publisher = The Johns Hopkins University | date = n.d. | accessdate = 11 November 2011 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://archive.is/20121210091339/http://writingseminars.jhu.edu/turnbull-lectures/history.html | archivedate = 10 December 2012 | df = }}</ref> <ref name="JHU turnbull2">{{cite web | url=http://blogs.library.jhu.edu/wordpress/?m=201102&paged=2 | title=The Sheridan Libraries Blog | date=15 Feb 2011 | author=Gabrielle Dean | accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> <ref name="JHU turnbull3">{{cite web | url=http://web.jhu.edu/announcements/faculty-staff/targetpage.html?baid=36026 | title=Faculty and Staff Announcements | publisher=The Johns Hopkins University | date=3 November 2011}}</ref> <ref name="knol mfa">{{cite web | url=http://knol.google.com/k/master-of-fine-arts-mfa-in-creative-writing-program-rankings | title=Master of Fine Arts in Creative Writing [Program Rankings] | date=24 August 2010 | publisher=Google | author=Seth Abramson | accessdate=11 November 2011 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111031110704/http://knol.google.com/k/master-of-fine-arts-mfa-in-creative-writing-program-rankings | archivedate=31 October 2011 | df= }}</ref> <ref name="PW 2011">{{cite web |url=http://www.pw.org/content/2012_mfa_rankings_the_top_fifty | title=The 2012 MFA Rankings: The Top Fifty | date= | publisher=Poets & Writers | accessdate=15 November 2011}}</ref> }}

page.title: List of law schools in Egypt

revision.comment: Rescuing 3 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
This is a list of schools in [[Egypt]] dedicated to the study of [[Law]].
'''Alexandria Governorate''' * [[Alexandria University]]: [https://web.archive.org/web/20160303194601/http://www.alex.edu.eg/?q=node%2F118&id=2.&name=Faculty%20of%20Law Faculty of Law] located in [[Alexandria]] * [[Pharos University in Alexandria]]: [http://www.pua.edu.eg/Page.aspx?Page=Faculties-%3ELegal+Studies+and+International+Relations Faculty of Legal Studies and International Relations] located in [[Alexandria]]
'''Asyut Governorate''' * [[Al-Azhar University]]: [https://web.archive.org/web/20100824214607/http://www.azhar.edu.eg/bfac/law-shariaa/ Faculty of Sharia and Law - Asyut Branch] {{ar icon}} located in [[Asyut]] * [[Assiut University]] located in [[Asyut]]
'''Beni Suef Governorate''' * [[Beni-Suef University]]: [https://web.archive.org/web/20100817004324/http://www.law.bsu.edu.eg/default.aspx Faculty of Law] located in [[Beni Suef]]
'''Cairo Governorate''' * [[Ain Shams University]]: [http://law.shams.edu.eg/ Faculty of Law] {{ar icon}} located in [[Cairo]] * [http://www.bue.edu.eg/index.php/law-home The British University in Egypt: Faculty of Law with dual certificates (British and Egyptian )] at El Sherouk City, Cairo * [[The American University in Cairo]]: [https://web.archive.org/web/20120606072355/http://www.aucegypt.edu/GAPP/Pages/Home.aspx School of Global Affairs and Public Policy] located in [[Cairo]]
'''Dakahlia Governorate''' * [[Mansoura University]]: [http://www.mans.edu.eg/faclaw/english/ Faculty of Law]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} located in [[Mansoura, Egypt|Mansoura]]
'''Gharbia Governorate''' * [[Al-Azhar University]]: [https://web.archive.org/web/20100902114727/http://www.azhar.edu.eg/bfac/shareaa_tanta/index.htm Faculty of Sharia and Law - Tanta Branch] {{ar icon}} located in [[Tanta]] * [[Tanta University]]: [https://web.archive.org/web/20100904171516/http://www.tanta.edu.eg/ar/Tanta/Law/index.html Faculty of Law] {{ar icon}} located in [[Tanta]]
'''Giza Governorate''' * [[Cairo University]]: [http://law.cu.edu.eg/ Faculty of Law] {{ar icon}} located in [[Giza]]
'''Helwan Governorate''' * [[Helwan University]]: [https://web.archive.org/web/20110115182727/http://www.helwan.edu.eg/english/www/lawen/index.html Faculty of Law] located in [[Helwan]]
'''Monufia Governorate''' * [[Minufiya University]] located in [[Shibin El Kom]]
'''Qalyubia Governorate''' * [[Banha University]]: [https://web.archive.org/web/20100830083506/http://www.benha-univ.edu.eg/site/colleages/hekok_details.html Faculty of Law] {{ar icon}} located in [[Banha]]
'''Qena Governorate''' * [[South Valley University]]: [http://www.svu.edu.eg/faculties/law/index.html Faculty of Law] located in [[Qena]]
'''Sharqia Governorate''' * [[Zagazig University]]: [https://web.archive.org/web/20100408015543/http://english.zu.edu.eg/index.php/institutes/law Faculty of Law] located in [[Zagazig]]

{{BLP sources|date=December 2015}}
'''Marion Walter''' (born July 30, 1928 in Berlin, [[Weimar Republic|Germany]]) is a mathematician who retired as Professor of Mathematics at [[University of Oregon]] in 1994. There is a theorem named after her, called Marion Walter's theorem.
==Education and early life== Born in Germany in 1928, she left on a ''[[Kindertransport]]'' to England where she attended a boarding school.<ref name="mwcoll">{{cite web|last1=Mead|first1=Carol|title=Introducing the Marion Walter Collection|url=https://www.maa.org/press/periodicals/maa-focus/introducing-the-marion-walter-collection|accessdate=14 April 2018}}</ref>
After she left school in December 1944 the school's only mathematics teacher resigned and since it was difficult to find a replacement during the war period, she was asked to teach maths, in part because she had earned a mark of distinction on her Cambridge University School Certificate exam. She taught for two terms and found she enjoyed teaching.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ruef|first1=Jennifer|title=Celebrating Marion Walter – and other unsung female mathematicians|url=https://theconversation.com/celebrating-marion-walter-and-other-unsung-female-mathematicians-92249|website=The Conversation|publisher=The Conversation Media Group|accessdate=23 March 2018}}</ref>
She attended college in England for two years before leaving for the United States in 1948. She then attended [[Hunter College]], majoring in mathematics and minoring in education, graduating in 1950.
After graduating, she taught at [[Hunter College High School]] and [[George Washington Educational Campus|George Washington High School]]. She began taking evening classes for a master's degree in mathematics at [[New York University]]. She worked as a research assistant, mainly doing computing work at what became the [[Courant Institute]].
In the summers of 1952 and 1953 she was awarded a [[National Institute of Standards and Technology|National Bureau of Standards]] summer scholarship to study at the Institute of Numerical Analysis at [[UCLA]].
She earned her master's degree in mathematics from [[New York University]] in 1954.
==Career== She accepted a teaching assistantship at [[Cornell University]]. In 1956, she took a one-year appointment at [[Simmons College]] in Boston. At the time, the college did not offer a major in mathematics but at the end of the year she was asked to create this major. Disliking the administrative aspects, she stepped down as department chair after four years, remaining there teaching until 1965 when she left to concentrate on her doctorate at [[Harvard Graduate School of Education]], earning an Ed.D. in 1967.
In 1960, she earned a fellowship to attend the National Science Foundation Summer Program at Stanford.
At Harvard, she formed a group called the Boston Area Math Specialists which gives monthly workshops for practicing teachers.<ref name="ams">{{cite web|title=About BAMS|url=https://www.bostonareamathspecialists.org/about-bams|website=Boston Area Math Specialists|accessdate=23 March 2018}}</ref>
She was a mathematics consultant to the project that became ''[[Sesame Street]]''.<ref>Charlene Morrow and Teri Peri (eds), ''Notable Women in Mathematics'', Greenwood Press, 1998, p 270</ref>
She worked briefly in Israel as a [[UNESCO]] consultant for mathematics teaching.
In 1977, she accepted a teaching position at [[University of Oregon]] where she remained until her retirement in 1994.<ref name="uocat">{{cite web|title=Mathematics Faculty|url=http://uocatalog.uoregon.edu/arts_sciences/mathematics/#facultytext|website=University of Oregon Catalog|publisher=University of Oregon|accessdate=23 March 2018}}</ref>
In 1993, Marion Walter's Theorem, which deals with the area of the hexagon formed by trisecting the sides of triangles, was named for her.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cuoco|first=Al|last2=Goldenberg|first2=Paul|last3=Mark|first3=June|date=1993|title=Marion's theorem|jstor=27968561|journal=The Mathematics Teacher|volume=86|issue=8|pages=619–619}}</ref>
== Books== She wrote a book on using mirrors to explore symmetry - Make a Bigger Puddle, Make a Smaller Worm (1971), which won an honourable mention from the New York Academy of Science Children's Book Award Program, as did her 1985 book ''The Mirror Puzzle Book''.<ref name="mwcoll"/>
*''Look at Annette'' (1971). *''Another, Another, Another and More'' (1975). *''The Art of Problem Posing'' (1983) - Co-authored with Stephen Brown. *''Boxes, Squares and Other Things'' (1970).
==References== {{Reflist|refs=}}
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Walter, Marion}} [[Category:1928 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:German mathematicians]] [[Category:Women mathematicians]] [[Category:20th-century mathematicians]] [[Category:Mathematics educators]] [[Category:Harvard Graduate School of Education alumni]] [[Category:Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences faculty]] [[Category:Hunter College alumni]] [[Category:University of Oregon faculty]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox scientist | name = Murray S. Klamkin | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1921|03|05}} | birth_place = | death_date = {{Death date and age|2004|08|06|1921|03|05}} | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | other_names = | residence = | citizenship = | nationality = United States | fields = [[Mathematics]] | workplaces = [[University at Buffalo, The State University of New York|SUNY Buffalo]]
[[University of Waterloo]]
[[University of Alberta]] | alma_mater = [[Polytechnic University of New York]] | thesis_title = | thesis_url = | thesis_year = | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | influences = | influenced = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = | spouse = | children = }} '''Murray Seymour Klamkin''' (March 5, 1921 – August 6, 2004) was an American [[mathematician]], known as prolific proposer and editor of professionally challenging mathematical problems. ==Life== Klamkin was born on March 5, 1921 in [[Brooklyn]], [[New York City|New York]]. He received a bachelor's degree from the [[Cooper Union]] in 1942 and, after four years of service in the United States Army, earned a master's degree from the [[Polytechnic University of New York|Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn]] in 1947, where he taught from 1948 until 1957. After this, Klamkin worked at [[AVCO]], taught at [[University at Buffalo, The State University of New York|SUNY Buffalo]] (1962–1964), and served as the principal research scientist at [[Ford Motor Company]] (1965–1976). During this period, he was also a visiting professor at the [[University of Minnesota]]. After leaving Ford, he became a professor at the [[University of Waterloo]].[http://www.maa.org/mathhorizons/volume/klamkin.htm ''Memorial Celebration of the Life of Murray Seymour Klamkin''], web page at the MAA, accessed 2007-01-11. From 1976 to 1981 Klamkin was the chairman of the Department of Mathematics at the [[University of Alberta]].[https://www.ualberta.ca/ARCHIVES/guide/3FACULTY/92.htm ''University of Alberta Archives: Faculty of Science''], web page at the University of Alberta, accessed 2007-01-11. After 1981 he became an [[emeritus]] professor at Alberta. Klamkin died August 6, 2004.[http://www.maa.org/sites/default/files/pdf/pubs/nov04.pdf ''Murray Klamkin, 1921-2004''], ''MAA FOCUS'' '''24''' (#8), November 2004, p. 32, accessed 2014-03-03. ==Mathematical problems== Klamkin was known worldwide as a prolific proposer and editor of professionally challenging mathematical problems. He served as problem editor for ''[[SIAM Review]]'', the ''[[American Mathematical Monthly]]'', and many other journals. He was also known for his work in high-level [[mathematics competitions]], such as the [[United States of America Mathematical Olympiad|USA Mathematical Olympiad]], the [[International Mathematical Olympiad]], and the [[William Lowell Putnam Mathematical Competition|Putnam Competition]]. In 1988 the [[Mathematical Association of America]] gave him its Award for Distinguished Service to Mathematics, its highest service award."Award for Distinguished Service to Prof. Murray Klamkin", [[Gerald L. Alexanderson]], ''[[American Mathematical Monthly]]'' '''95''' (#1), January 1988, pp. 1–4. In 1992, the [[World Federation of National Mathematics Competitions]] awarded Klamkin the [[David Hilbert Award]] for his contributions to mathematics competitions.[http://www.amt.edu.au/wfnmcaw.html ''David Hilbert and Paul Erdös Awards''], web page at the WFNMC, accessed 2014-03-03. ==Selected bibliography== * "The asymmetric propeller", Leon Bankoff, Paul Erdös, and Murray S. Klamkin, ''Mathematics Magazine'' '''46''', #5 (November 1973), pp. 270–272. * ''International Mathematical Olympiads, 1978–1985 and Forty Supplementary Problems'', ed. Murray S. Klamkin, pub. Washington, DC: [[Mathematical Association of America]], 1986. {{ISBN|0-88385-631-X}}. * ''Mathematical Modelling: Classroom Notes in Applied Mathematics'', ed. Murray S. Klamkin, pub. Philadelphia, PA: [[Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics]], 1987. {{ISBN|0-89871-204-1}}. * ''U.S.A. Mathematical Olympiads, 1972–1986'', ed. Murray S. Klamkin, pub. Washington, DC: Mathematical Association of America, 1988. {{ISBN|0-88385-634-4}}. * ''Problems in Applied Mathematics: Selections from SIAM Review'', ed. Murray S. Klamkin, pub. Philadelphia, PA: Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics, 1990. {{ISBN|0-89871-259-9}}. * ''Five Hundred Mathematical Challenges'', Edward J. Barbeau, Murray S. Klamkin, and William O. J. Moser, pub. Washington, DC: Mathematical Association of America, 1995. {{ISBN|0-88385-519-4}}. * {{cite book | editor1-last = Liu | editor1-first = Andy | editor2-last = Shawyer | editor2-first = Bruce | title = Problems from Murray Klamkin | publisher = Mathematical Association of America | location = Washington | year = 2008 | isbn = 978-0-88385-828-8 }} A collection of problems posed by Klamkin in ''[[Crux Mathematicorum with Mathematical Mayhem]]''. * ''On cooking a roast'', Murray S. Klamkin. ''SIAM Review'' 3.2 (1961): 167-169. ==References== {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Klamkin, Murray S.}} [[Category:1921 births]] [[Category:2004 deaths]] [[Category:Canadian mathematicians]] [[Category:Mathematics educators]] [[Category:20th-century American mathematicians]] [[Category:21st-century American mathematicians]] [[Category:Polytechnic Institute of New York University alumni]] [[Category:Polytechnic Institute of New York University faculty]] [[Category:University at Buffalo faculty]] [[Category:University of Waterloo faculty]] [[Category:University of Alberta faculty]]

A '''Neighbourhood Action Group''', or NAG, is a [[UK]] initiative, set up to deal with key issues identified by a community's first public consultation. The group is coordinated by the [[police]].This may happen in the form of a public meeting, through surveys done face-to-face or by mail, or a combination of methods.
NAGs are volunteer working groups made up of representatives from the community.They will include residents, the police, local authority and other organisations, such as local businesses and schools. Ideally NAGs represent a cross section of the society they represent, including representatives from groups such as [[neighbourhood watch]] schemes and local councils.
They are key to the success of neighbourhood policing as it is this group which will plan on behalf of the community and organise for tasks to be completed. In effect, they are the 'doers', accountable locally for responding to problems a community wants to tackle.<ref>http://www.thamesvalley.police.uk</ref>
== NAG Members == The NAG constitution <ref>http://www.thamesvalley.police.uk/nagterms.pdf</ref> suggests the following should be invited to join the NAG: * Residents including young people * [[Civil parishes in England|Parish]] and [[Wards of the United Kingdom|Ward]] [[Councillor]]s * Representatives from the business community * Neighbourhood Watch co-ordinators * Local policing team including [[Police community support officer]]s (PCSO)
== Priority Profiles ==
Every NAG has three priority profiles - priorities for the neighbourhood policing team to address, with the assistance of NAG members. These are reviewed annually and those outside of the NAG are invited to contribute.<ref>http://www.thamesvalley.police.uk/nagterms.pdf</ref>
== References == {{reflist|2}}
== External links == *[http://www.uknags.org.uk/ National NAG website portal] *[http://www.uknags.org.uk/view_group.php?nag=1 Website for the Upper Caversham, Reading, Berkshire area: Upper Caversham NAG (Reading, Berkshire, UK)] *[http://www.uknags.org.uk/view_group.php?nag=2 Website for the Lower Caversham, Reading, Berkshire area: Lower Caversham NAG (Reading, Berkshire, UK)]
[[Category:Community organizing]] [[Category:Law enforcement agencies of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Neighborhood watch organizations]]
